node.title: Becoming a Parent, or Deciding Not To
node.description: Betty Rollin and other readers discuss whether it is “still OK to procreate.” Also: Following the kids’ lead on masks; regulating cyberwar.
node.content: ["To the Editor:", "Re \u201cIn an Age Like This, Is It Still OK to Procreate?\u201d (Sunday Styles, Nov. 21):", "In a way I admire the young women who are thinking twice about becoming mothers because the future climate may be unlivable. Quite a contrast from some other young women who become mothers without thinking about anything much, like whether a man \u2014 or a woman \u2014 is likely to stick around to help out. Or whether, besides finding babies cute, she really likes them. Or whether, as the children grow, she will continue to like them \u2014 and their needs.", "All of that can be hard to predict, but before making a decision that not only changes one\u2019s life but also creates a life that demands so much, one should stop to consider more than most do.", "When I was young, I wrote a cover story about all of that in the long-defunct Look magazine. As a result, hundreds of subscribers canceled their subscriptions and many wrote horrified letters.", "I\u2019ll make the same obvious point now that I made then: Some people are not cut out to be mothers. They don\u2019t like the nature of the work. They don\u2019t like the cost. They don\u2019t like not sleeping much. Etc., etc. Then, as we all know, bad things can happen, both to the unloving mother and the unloved child.", "I myself wound up not having children because I got breast cancer and my doctor warned me that it would be dangerous for me to get pregnant. And things worked out just fine. I finally married someone I adored, and we had almost 42 blissful years loving each other and loving our work and feeling lucky.", "Last year, while he was on his way to dying, he used to joke that it might be helpful to adopt a 60-year-old. But no, he said, on second thought, he or she would talk too much.", "So, young ladies, my advice is whatever the climate is doing, have children if you want \u2014 life is always risky \u2014 but make sure it\u2019s something you really want to do.", "Betty RollinNew YorkThe writer is a former TV correspondent and the author of \u201cFirst, You Cry\u201d and \u201cLast Wish.\u201d", "To the Editor:", "There are many reasons indeed to be hesitant about procreating, but procreation is not a prerequisite for becoming a parent.", "There are more than 400,000 children in foster care in the United States. They are already here, and they will be all the more vulnerable exactly because of the very things people quoted in the article are afraid of: global instability wrought by climate change, political upheaval and racial injustice.", "Don\u2019t simply turn away because, as Seth Rogen is quoted in the article, \u201cthere\u2019s enough kids out there.\u201d Consider doing something about it by adopting a child from foster care.", "We adopted four, and it continues to be the most challenging thing we\u2019ve ever undertaken, but these kids deserve to be loved and cared for especially during these trying times.", "Darin BrunstadDavid BrunstadSimsbury, Conn.", "To the Editor:", "\u201cIn an Age Like This, Is It Still OK to Procreate?\u201d makes it clear that some women of childbearing age have been so emotionally affected by the pandemic as to question whether to ever bring a child into the world at all.", "While we women have always had the childbearing weight on our shoulders, many of us came from other times of good and bad and decided to have children.", "My mother was neither spiritual or religious, but she always said that \u201ca baby brings his own blessings into the world.\u201d", "I brought three children into the world, and while married when bearing them brought them up quite by myself. And yet I never look back and say I should have decided otherwise.", "My children, now in their 40s, have given me nine grandchildren. That\u2019s nine birthdays, nine sets of Hanukkah gifts, nine graduations, etc. Children are the only gift a woman can give herself that is never the wrong color, size or type. They come into this imperfect world, equally imperfect, just like their parents. But they\u2019re perfect nonetheless.", "It is vital for women to have the ultimate choice as to whether or not to bear children. But those who choose not to are denying themselves the greatest gift in the world.", "Renee M. DuckerWhiting, N.J.", "To the Editor:", "Re \u201cWhen Can the Covid Masks Finally Come Off?\u201d (news article, nytimes.com, Nov. 20):", "Every day, my kids (ages 9 and 7) put on their masks before going to school. They do not ask about cases per 100,000 people or the positivity rate or what percentage of our county is vaccinated. They just wear their masks. They understand that a lot of people are still getting sick, and wearing masks indoors keeps them and those around them safer. That\u2019s good enough for them.", "It is not, however, good enough for adults. The public health guidance is clear: Wear a mask indoors in public settings if your area is experiencing substantial or high transmission. But adults put our convenience and comfort ahead of the health and safety of others \u2014 including children who are either not yet fully vaccinated or remain ineligible for vaccination.", "Pretending a pandemic doesn\u2019t exist won\u2019t make it go away. Refusing to wear masks will push the end of that pandemic even further away.", "Children get it. Adults do not. If only we were as good as they are at acting like grown-ups.", "Adam ZimmermanRockville, Md.", "To the Editor:", "\u201cIsrael and Iran Widen Targets in a Cyberwar\u201d (front page, Nov. 28) is a warning of a danger that threatens us all.", "There is no guarantee that cyberattacks will be limited to causing long gas lines or the publication of embarrassing dating information. Hackers could attack air traffic control, hospitals or even nuclear command and control.", "The United States is missing a major opportunity for arms control. The U.S. government should sponsor an international convention to regulate cyberwar.", "Truly dangerous attacks should be in violation of international law. If such an attack can be traced to an individual or group, it should be subject to international criminal prosecution. If traced to a nation, it should be subject to harsh sanctions.", "The United States must not set the dangerous precedent of relying on offensive cyberwar as a deterrent. It is a formula for global chaos.", "David KeppelBloomington, Ind."]
